title: CTRL0000917178 - Transcribed Interview of Cassie Docksey, (Aug. 25, 2022)

data.text: SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE THE
JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES,
WASHINGTON, D.C.
INTERVIEW OF:
CASSIE DOCKSEY
Thursday, August 25, 2022
Washington, D.C.
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 11:01 a.m.
Appearances:
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE

McGuireWoods
888 16th Street NW, Suite 500
Black Lives Matter Plaza
Washington, D.C. 20006

conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.

are no other people in the room here.

transcribed interview.

reporter transcription is the official record of the proceeding.
audio- and video-recorded.

unclear, please ask for clarification.

January '21?

In August of 2017.

Right before the RNC, I was on Capitol Hill as the communications director
I have a bachelor's degree from Marquette University, graduated in
for Senator Todd Young from Indiana.

When you joined the RNC in August of 2017, what was your role?
A
I was the national press secretary.

A
I primarily took the incoming reporter requests and then pitched and placed
stories about the RNC, you know, our field program, how many doors we'd knocked,
volunteers, things like that.
Q
And who did you report to while national press secretary?
A
The deputy communications director was a gal by the name of Lindsay
Jancek, and the communications director was Ryan Mahoney.
Q
And how do you spell "Jancek"?
A
J-a-n-c-e-k.
Q
Did your title at some point change from national press secretary to
something else?
A
In January of 2019, I was promoted to the deputy communications director.
Q
And did your responsibilities change?
A
Yes.
They grew, and I was no longer the primary person to pitch and place
the stories.
Q
What were your new responsibilities?
A
So the communications and research department at the RNC has a lot of
subdivisions -- rapid response or the specialty medias, or regional media is the booking
operation, and then the national press team.
the message or the task for each of those subdivisions, if we had a message that we
wanted everybody to be on message about.
So primarily I would help to coordinate

GOP accounts.
I approved their social.
some of the approval for the fundraising emails, the small-dollar fundraising emails.

Yes.

Let's finish going through your background at the RNC, and then

A
Okay.

No, not at the RNC.

A
January of 2021.

A
So I started my new job at America Rising on January 11th.

So you left the RNC sometime between the 1st and the 11th?
A
Yes.
So, if the 11th was probably a Monday -- so my last day would've been
that Friday.
So, because of the holidays and COVID, people weren't at the office, so they
just gave me a little bit of a grace period to be able to -- I went to the last winter meeting
that week prior, to be able to say bye to people.
I wasn't, like, actively still doing a lot of the work but I was still on payroll so that I could
have that opportunity.
So that's why it's a little funny, because
Q
Let's move to the year -- well, in your role as deputy com ms director, who did you

A
Okay.
And if that changed over '19 through '20, if you could let us know.
So, for that whole cycle, '19 and '20, I reported to Michael Ahrens, who was
the communications director, and then Mike Reed, who was the deputy chief of staff for
communications and research.
So I sort of reported to them interchangeably.
Q
Did you understand Mr. Reed to report to Mr. Ahrens, or no?
A
No.
Q
And who did you understand them to report to?
A
Probably Richard Walters, the chief of staff, would've probably been their
primary person.
Q
I would put them on the same level, on the same plane.
And in your work in the fall of the 2020 cycle, did you have a lot of

A
A fair amount.
I was no longer the primary person who would go with her
to media appearances or things like that, like I did in the press secretary role, but I would
see her from time to time.

Would you ever attend meetings with her at the White House?
A
No, I didn't do that with her.

All right.

For the approval process?
So, from the RNC side, we had a

And then I understood that there was a team from the campaign that I think was
largely parallel to us.
a com ms approver and a legal person.

As the comms approver, what did you understand your

So, for the emails that were primarily campaign-focused messaging or
coming from a campaign surrogate, my primary role was to make sure that everything

know, because they would come in these big digest forms, so it was a lot of copy that
they would copy and paste over -- you know, the links worked.
make sure that there weren't any glaring errors from that standpoint on these emails.
And then, if it was more RNC-focused, maybe from the chairwoman, then I would
look to make sure it aligned with her public statements on that topic.

And is that what you were directed from either Mr. Reed or Mr. Ahrens of
how to handle your role?
A
I actually don't recall that they ever gave a clear directive or directions on
how this should be done.
that out as my niche, to make sure that that box got checked.

A
Yes, I think that's fair to say.

Definitely.
that nothing glaring was wrong.
wrong or that didn't work that you were looking for?

So I'd flag that as something that they should correct.
landing page that didn't seem to fit, then I would flag that.
like that.

Well, we'll talk about specific emails and especially the post-election

But I'm just trying to get a sense of, when you

job to revise this, make this better, to kind of deal with that in a substantive way, as

When you were reviewing those, were you looking at that and thinking, it's my

Oh, okay.

-- as opposed to the kind of things we've just talked about -- typos, links,

A
Uh-huh.
So, if it was a campaign message, clearly something, like we've

look at it from a substance standpoint.
I might've from time to time said, "Is this what
he said?" or, "Does this match his voice?"
You know, there might have been some
commentary.
I'm not speaking or thinking of anything specifically.
And they would
point to a tweet or something that they drew this from.
the campaign, I left that to them and their approval chain.

dialogue with the copywriting folks who came up with the email or dialogue with the

you good with that?"

Q
So is it fair to say that when a campaign-focused email came across your
desk for approval, you didn't see it as your job to revise the substance of the email if
there weren't otherwise glaring errors, such as typos or an odd reading to the casual
reader, for example?
A
Right, I did not see that as my primary role.
I saw my primary role as just
looking for glaring typo errors, but not to look at the substance of the email, if that helps.
Q
Now, you mentioned that legal was also on the approval chain for the RNC.
What did you understand legal to be doing on the chain?
A
What lawyers do.
They would usually go through it just to make sure, I
think, that things from their perspective were as clear as they could be, or they just made
edits that I felt, you know, always -- I'm trying to think of the right word -- like, a cleaner
way to phrase something or something like that.
So I just viewed them as taking their legal eye to it.
I don't know exactly what
they were looking for.
Q
Let's move to research.
What did you understand research to be doing?
A
So, based on how the RNC research approached their research documents
that they would send out from the RNC, and so I would say this was probably the same
eye that they were taking here, just to make sure if they were saying, you know,
"Forty percent chance of rain today," and they'd go through and say, "Actually, it's a
65 percent chance of rain today," you know, for example.
So just to say publicly available information, that all of that was consistent with
what was publicly available from the RNC side.
they approached their own research documents.
Q
Again, that's my understanding of how
So would an example be, the email says, "President Trump in Pennsylvania
said X, Y, Z," they would go check that is Pennsylvania the right place where he actually

A
So I actually don't know.
In that case, my assumption would be that would
be more of the campaign side, to check that.
That's not to say that they didn't or that
they wouldn't feel compelled to check that.
I just don't know if that was how he
thought about it.
I'm sorry I don't know.

Yeah.
So much of this was just an email chain.
So is it fair to say that there were not meetings that were held

Is that fair to say?
A
Yes.
I don't recall any meetings like that.

So there was no, in a sense, coordination between the RNC approval side

came back and forth on specific chains.
A
discussed.
no established meeting that I'm aware of.

There might have been a one-off conversation between folks, but certainly

Yes.
That's my recollection, that people would put in their edits, and then

point we got it after they reviewed it, but then I think it switched.

specifically.
